section.name: NURSING CARE OF THE OLDER ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
This course is an overview that integrates selected theoretical information into research-based nursing care of the older adult. The overview includes principles of gerontological care; specialized ns; assessment of the older adult; effects of physiological aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems associated with aging, with special attention to family issues; pharmacological, nutritional, and ethical considerations; and the settings where older persons are the recipients of care. The clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and emphasizes transitional care for older adults across the health care continuum.

Students generally found this course to be "fantastic" and "informative." Many remarked that they learned a lot from it. Several agreed that the material was "well-organized" and "enriching."

The course was taught by Professor Trotta, Professor Kagan, and Professor Quigley. Students generally found the instructors to be "inspiring," "receptive to questions," and "engaging."

Although the readings were "helpful," many students agreed that they were "cumbersome" and that there were "too many to feasibly complete." The exams were "incredibly long and overwhelming," but "fair." Overall, students enjoyed the course but found it challenging. The pre-requisites for this course are NURS 104, 106, 131, and 132.

section.name: NURSING CARE OF THE OLDER ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:

Students generally found this course to be "fantastic" and "informative." Many remarked that they learned a lot from it. Several agreed that the material was "well-organized" and "enriching."

The course was taught by Professor Trotta, Professor Kagan, and Professor Quigley. Students generally found the instructors to be "inspiring," "receptive to questions," and "engaging."

Although the readings were "helpful," many students agreed that they were "cumbersome" and that there were "too many to feasibly complete." This course is an overview that integrates selected theoretical information into research-based nursing care of the older adult. The overview includes principles of gerontological care; specialized ns; assessment of the older adult; effects of physiological aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems associated with aging, with special attention to family issues; pharmacological, nutritional, and ethical considerations; and the settings where older persons are the recipients of care. The clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and emphasizes transitional care for older adults across the health care continuum.

While many students found the course material to be beneficial and valuable, there were many comments about disorganized teaching methods, "a major lack of continuity" between what is taught and what is tested, unclear objectives and expectations, and inconsistencies among different instructors and lab groups.

This course was the laboratory component, taught by Professor Iorianni-Cimbak. One student remarked that the professor was "available to discuss course matters and scheduling difficulties." Reviews for individual lab instructors were mixed, but many students remarked that expectations and grading practices varied greatly, rendering validations and exams "incredibly difficult."

Students generally preferred practical lab exercises to the tedious "treasure hunt" of written modules. Many found the heavy readings to be "torturous," "frustrating," and "unrealistic." Many students also remarked that the written modules were "time-consuming.” Overall, students agreed that the course was "informative" but would be more helpful if it were reorganized. The pre-requisites for this course are NURS 104, 106, 131, and 132.
